'''Goblin-town''' was an [[Orcs#Goblins and Orcs|Orc]] dwelling under the [[Misty Mountains]], which was ruled by the [[Great Goblin]].

Goblin-town was a series of tunnels and caverns, which went all the way through the mountains, with a "[[Goblin-gate|back door]]" near the [[Eagle's Eyrie]] in [[Rhovanion|Wilderland]], which served as a means of escape, and an access to the Wilderland.<ref name=pan>{{H|Pan}}</ref> A cave with a lake was deep beneath Goblin-town yet was connected to the Orcs' tunnels, with one passage leading to the "back door".<ref name=rid>{{H|Riddles}}</ref>

== History ==
Long before the coming of the [[Orcs of the Misty Mountains]], [[nameless things]] were living in the caves.<ref name=rid/> Around {{TA|2480}} the [[Orcs of the Misty Mountains]] started making secret strongholds in the mountains blocking the passages towards [[Eriador]]<ref name=ta/> and expanded those caves, digging tunnels to connect them; without their knowledge they drove those slimy creatures into dark corners. One of those "original owners" was [[Gollum]], who was living at [[Gollum's lake|a nearby underground lake]], feeding himself on raw fish as well as Orcs that he killed.<ref name=rid/>

The main gate of the town was in one of the passes of the Misty Mountains, but by {{TA|2941}}<ref name=ta>{{app|TA}}</ref> travellers learned to avoid that dangerous road and the Orcs opened another under the safer [[High Pass]]: The [[Front Porch]]).<ref name=pan/>

During the journey to [[Lonely Mountain]], [[Thorin and Company]] rested in a cave and were captured by the Orcs. They were brought before the Great Goblin, who accused them of spying, and was enraged when he found that Thorin was carrying [[Orcrist]], a sword the Great Goblin remembered from [[Gondolin]]. With the help of [[Gandalf]], the Great Goblin was slain and Bilbo and the Dwarves escaped, pursued by a force of Orcs.<ref>{{H|Hill}}</ref>

== Portrayal in adaptations ==
'''1977: [[The Hobbit (1977 film)|''The Hobbit'' (1977 film)]]:'''
:Goblin-town is, like in the book, a set of tunnels and caverns.

'''1989: [[The Hobbit (comic book)|''The Hobbit'' (comic book)]]:'''
:Goblin-town is, like in the book, a set of tunnels and caverns.

'''2003: [[The Hobbit (2003 video game)|''The Hobbit'' (2003 video game)]]:'''
:Goblin-town is a giant Dwarven mining complex with many lifts, bridges and train carts to spice up the action of the level.

[[File:The Lord of the Rings Online - Goblin-town.jpg|thumb|250px|Goblin-town in ''[[The Lord of the Rings Online]]'']]
'''2007: ''[[The Lord of the Rings Online]]'':'''
:One of the first new additions to the game after the initial release, Goblin-town proper is a large network of tunnels and caverns accessible from the eastern part of the [[Misty Mountains]] region. It is a labyrinthine network of hallways, bridges and caves with many side passages. Great Goblin's Throne Room and [[Gollum's lake|Gollum's Cave]] are two of the natural endpoints of the exploration. Goblin-town was revisited in the "Seat of the Great Goblin" group instance that greatly streamlined the layout with the focus on the Throne Room. Another version of Goblin-town is accessible from the eastern entrance in the [[Vales of Anduin]] region. This version also contains the Throne Room, with all three versions of it being slightly different from one another.

'''2012: ''[[The Hobbit: An Unexpected Journey]]'':'''
:Goblin-town is portrayed as a giant system of caverns with sprawling wooden walkways. The goblins have a central hub of dwellings, with the Great Goblin's throne being in the center.
